doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Nomura/Japan August 2025 Tokyo CPI - Inflation on a downward trajectory despite sticky food price inflationJapan August 2025 To_2025-08-29

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Nomura

passages.text: Caution about: (1) depressive impact of scrapping childcare fees in September; and (2) impact of supply of high- priced new 2025 rice

Tokyo core CPI inflation came to \(+2.5\%\) in August. Inflation slowed for a third straight month, mainly due to measures to rein in electricity and gas charges. Rice prices are now pushing down inflation, but food inflation as a whole looked sticky, holding steady from the previous month. We think inflation in September could be affected by the negative impact of free childcare being implemented and the supply of newly harvested rice.

Overview: Core CPI inflation in line with market consensus, down m- m Tokyo core CPI inflation (all items less fresh food) came to \(+2.5\%\) in August 2025, down from \(+2.9\%\) in July (Figure 1) and in line with the consensus forecast (Bloomberg survey median). The BOJ's version of core- core CPI inflation (all items, less energy and fresh food) came to \(+3.0\%\) , slowing from \(+3.1\%\) in the previous month. Inflation for all items excluding energy and food (but including alcoholic beverages) came to \(+1.5\%\) , down from \(+1.7\%\) in the previous month. Like these y- y rates of inflation, m- m inflation has also been trending downward (Figure 7).

Breakdown: (1) Slowdown in inflation mainly due to energy prices; (2) bigger negative contribution from rice prices, but food price inflation unchanged The main factor behind the decline in core CPI inflation was energy prices (- 0.26ppt m- m change in contribution to y- y inflation). This reflects the effect of government measures to rein in electricity and gas charges in summer 2025 (Figure 6). These measures will last for three months through October.

Meanwhile, inflation in core food prices (food less fresh food and alcoholic beverages) came to \(+7.5\%\) , unchanged from July. We had expected food inflation to fall slightly in August, but it has been stickier than we had expected. Prices for rice products were down m- m for a second straight month, pushing down inflation (Figure 6). However, price rises for other items such as chocolate, yogurt, and chicken offset the impact of the lull in the rise in rice prices.

Durable goods prices made a large negative contribution this month (- 0.06ppt m- m change in contribution to y- y inflation). As this category is readily affected by forex rates, we think the strengthening of the yen since the start of the year has had a delayed impact. Services prices, which reflect the underlying inflation trend, held broadly flat. Spending on general services (a rough proxy for private- sector services), which strips out volatile items, was up \(2.0\%\) y- y in August, unchanged from July (Figure 8).
Key points to watch in September: (1) scrapping of childcare fees; and (2) increased supply of new rice

Looking ahead, we expect the rollout of free childcare in Tokyo from September to depress core CPI inflation by around 0.5ppt. We should also not ignore the impact of the gradual start of supply of new rice from the 2025 harvest. Rice is still being procured by buyers at high prices, as evidenced by the sharp y- y increase in provisional payments for rice (prepayments made by Japan Agricultural Cooperative Associations and other collection agents to farmers), and we think this will support continued food price inflation.
Fig. 1: Contributions to \(\%\) y-y change in Tokyo core CPI (excluding impact of the consumption tax hike and free education)

Note: Core CPI = CPI for all items, excluding fresh food. Excluding impact of April 2014 consumption tax hike and impact of October 2019 consumption tax hike, October 2019 start of free preschool education, and April 2020 start of free higher education. Nondurable goods is based on the nondurable consumer goods category published by MIC excluding food (food here excludes restaurants), electricity charges, city gas charges, propane gas, kerosene and gasoline, but including alcoholic beverages.
Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications data
Fig. 2: Tokyo core CPI (excluding impact of the consumption tax hike and free education) by goods or services category

Note: Core CPI = CPI for all items, excluding fresh food. It excludes the impact of the consumption tax increases of April 2014 and October 2019, the abolition of fees for preschool education in October 2019, and the abolition of fees for higher education in April 2020. Nondurables are "nondurable goods" as described by the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications, excluding foods, electricity charges, city gas charges, propane gas, kerosene, and gasoline but including alcohol. Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications data

Note: Nondurable consumer goods is based on the nondurable consumer goods category published by MIC excluding food (ex eating out and alcoholic beverages), electricity charges, city gas charges, propane gas, kerosene and gasoline, but including alcoholic beverages. Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications data
Fig. 4: Tokyo ku-area consumer price index
Note: Excludes impact of the consumption tax hike in October 2019 as well as the removal of fees for preschool education from October 2019 and higher education from April 2020.
Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications data
Fig. 5: Inflation rate for goods and services
Note: Covers items included in Tokyo ku-area/Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications core core CPI (all items less food (ex alcoholic beverages) and energy).
Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications data
Fig. 6: Items making the biggest positive/negative contribution to core inflation (August 2025)

TopItemContribution to all- Japan core CPI (ppt)BottomItemContribution to all- Japan core CPI (ppt)1Chocolate0.0231Electricity-0.1922Room air conditioners0.0202Gas, manufactured and piped-0.0813Yogurt0.0193Non-glutinous rice-B-0.0334Chicken0.0174Electric rice cookers-0.0255Fresh milk0.0155Detergent, laundry-0.0216Telephone charges (mobile phone)0.0136Non-glutinous rice-A-0.0207Gasoline0.0137Overseas package tours-0.0158Pudding0.0128Pork (imported)-0.0149Pants for exercise0.0119Washing machines-0.01310Jelly0.01110Toilet seat with a hot douche-0.01211Anpan (sweet rolls filled with red bean paste0.01011Vacuum cleaners-0.01012Sushi (eating out, B)0.00912Sushi (eating out, A)-0.00913Sandwich products0.00813Tea beverages-0.00914Women's suits (spring/summer, mid-range r)0.00714Beef bowls (eating out)-0.00815Fire and earthquake insurance0.00715One-piece dresses (for spring &amp; summer)-0.008

Note: The table shows the contribution of each item to the rise in (m-m change in the y-y contribution to) core inflation between July and August 2025. Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications data
Fig. 7: : M-m change in Tokyo CPI inflation
Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications data
Fig. 8: General services excluding impact of volatile items (y-y)

Note: (1) Excludes restaurants, telephone charges (mobile phones), private rents, imputed rents for owner- occupied houses, theme park admission fees, car rental fees, karaoke room charges, overseas package tours, accommodation charges, after- school childcare fees, and charges for practicing and playing golf. (2) Excludes impact of consumption tax hike, tree education.
Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications data
